text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single column of Latin text arranged around a large historiated initial; extensive foliate borders fill wide margins; the initial interrupts the line and encloses the main scene within its letterform

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata, professional book hand with uniform letterforms, regular line justification, red rubrication

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf highlights divine elements and background diaper pattern; ultramarine reserved for David’s robe and border scrolls; red for cloak and rubrics; alternating pink and green acanthus in margins; layered pigment with white or ochre highlighting on folds; overall well-preserved with minimal pigment loss

features: vertical axis from David to God
rectangular interior space with patterned floor

decorative_elements: acanthus leaf scrolls with punch-work dots
batons of alternating colored diamonds in line fillers
floral sprays emanating from vine stems

drawing_technique.line_style: Fine quill-pen outlines in brown ink with varying weight for figures and foliage
drawing_technique.shading_method: Subtle hatching in drapery folds and minimal tinted washes to model volume; white highlighting on blue robe
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling (God smaller, elevated); no true linear perspective; overlapping of figures suggests depth

content_theme.scene_description: Within the historiated initial (likely the letter D), King David kneels on a red-tiled floor at lower left, hands raised in prayer. He wears a long blue robe with red cloak, haloed in burnished gold. His hair and beard are stroked with fine lines. Above him, God the Father emerges from a gilt cloud, holding an open scroll inscribed with text. The interior field is dark blue with repeating gold lozenges. The initial’s frame is rich red with green infill. Surrounding text in black ink and red rubrics fills the page; the large initial interrupts the line. The decorative margins feature tall foliate stems sprouting acanthus leaves in blue, pink and green, with punched gold dots. In the lower margin, swirling foliate grotesques echo colors of the main scene. The composition centers on the divine-human encounter, with David’s gesture and gaze leading the viewer upward to the scroll-bearing deity. The lavish border and initial unify text and image, guiding devotional focus.

natural: twining vine scroll with acanthus leaves

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum with uniform parchment thickness; flesh side extremely smooth; ruled lightly in plummet for text lines; gathered in quaternion folios
technical_features.preservation_condition: Vivid pigments with minimal oxidation; slight abrasion at upper margin; minor flaking of red pigment; evidence of modern stabilization

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This leaf, likely from a mid-14th-century French psalter, exemplifies the courtly aesthetic and devotional emphasis of its time. Crafted on high-quality calf vellum with a professional Gothic textura hand, the page bears hallmarks of a luxury workshop, perhaps associated with Parisian illuminators serving aristocratic patrons. The historiated initial portraying David receiving the divine word reflects a theological program linking royal authority to divine inspiration, underscored by the burnished gold and ultramarine pigments reserved for sacred figures. The inventive use of layered washes and white highlighting in drapery achieves a subtle naturalism uncommon in earlier manuscripts, suggesting an awareness of panel painting techniques. The extensive foliate borders with acanthus scrolls and grotesque forms demonstrate the integration of secular ornamental motifs into sacred contexts, reflecting the growing taste for visual spectacle in private devotion. Iconographically, the scroll held by God underscores the power of the psalm text itself, inviting the reader to enter into David’s act of worship. Comparatively, this page shares stylistic affinities with the Psalter of Jeanne of Évreux, particularly in its refined line work and border innovation. It represents a moment of transition toward more personalized liturgical books, combining tradition and novelty to serve both spiritual and social functions.
